Authors: Masahide Yamato, Muneyuki Ohmae, Takamichi Orihara
Title:
A sporocarp-forming arbuscular mycorrhizal fungus Glomus
microcarpum is recombined with the genus Kamienskia (Glomeraceae)
according to its phylogenetic position
Keywords:
arbuscular mycorrhiza, Glomeromycotina, molecular
phylogeny, morphology, rDNA
Abstract:
The majority of recent studies on arbuscuar mycorhizal
(AM) fungi have dealt with species that produce single spores in soil
despite the fact that some species form sporocarps, that is, the
aggregates of spores. Most sporocarp-forming AM fungi belong to the
genus Glomus sensu lato, but their phylogenetic positions remain unknown
due to lack of their molecular data. In the course of field surveys of
truffle-like fungi throughout Japan, we collected sporocarps that had
identical morphological characteristics to those of Glomus microcarpum
Tul. & C. Tul. from several localities. Although G. microcarpum is
one of the first described Glomus species, its phylogenetic position
remains unknown thus far. We therefore conducted phylogenetic analyses
based on partial 18Sinternal transcribed spacerpartial 28S (SSU-ITS-LSU)
regions of nuclear rDNA, which are recommended as the barcoding regions
for AM fungi. The resultant trees indicated that this species is
genetically distant to any of the genera included in the latest
consensus classification of Glomaraceae (i.e., Glomus, Funneliformis,
Rhizophagus, Sclerocystis, and Septoglomus), but is nested within the
recently described genus Kamienskia Błaszk., Chwat & Kovács in this
family. Accordingly, we propose a new combination Kamienskia microcarpa
(Tul. & C. Tul.) Yamato & Orihara for G. microcarpum.
